children.subject: OP here. Is it ok to say "I changed my mind" weeks after accepting the offer? Won't you need to sign something when you accept it saying "I wont change my mind or I pay fines" or something like that?

California is an at-will employment state, which, to the best of my understanding, means that you can renege a job offer (or quit a job) at any time for any reason without legal consequences.  There is a large potential you may be burning the bridge though and likely will not be able to return to that company.
tell company A that you need more time. tell company B that you have an offer deadline. If neither co-operates, accept A and if you get B later tell A that you changed your mind.

history.content:
https://career.berkeley.edu/Handshake/JobOffer

"For all offers extended for summer internships or full-time employment, employers should allow students until October 1 or a minimum of two weeks from the date of the written offer, whichever is later, for students to accept or decline any offer." - from above

Send this to your recruiter and ask for the 2 weeks to decide about the summer internship and say its UC Berkeley policy.

children.subject:
Worst case scenario you can renege your offer from startup A if you get an offer from company B. However, I would do the following before that scenario: 

1. email recruiter from A to give you more time to decide

2. email recruiter from B to speed up your process, tell them your situation

If you're in a position down the road and you decide to renege your offer, it's possible that that company can in some way blacklist you for future opportunities. It can sever your ties with them, and they can contact the school career center about you, but hey, if its a company you don't see yourself working at in the near future, I wouldn't care too much about it.

i couldn't really tell from the post if this was the case, but also be careful of exploding offers, they can be a little sketchy.
completely agree with the advice from the posts above. definitely email B saying you have an existing offer and need to expedite. for company A, in addition to pulling up the policy recommendation, you can also say things like you have exams or need to consult with others to make a fully informed decision

hold out and have faith in yo self u can land something you'll love (like company B)

and keep up the leetcode + application grind

imo you'll b a sad boi if u settle for A

history.content:
So I just got an internship offer from a startup A, and the gig is basically making a phone app. The pay quite a bit lower than the norm in the Bay cuz they're a startup.

However, I interviewed another internship earlier at a mid-sized company B, and I feel there's some possibility that I can get an offer. This internship is still SWE mostly, but slightly more machine learning involved, which I think is more interesting than the phone app development one that I got.

I just had a first round phone screen with company B today, but company A asked me whether I can get decide on the offer next Monday, and I said maybe yes. I think my options are: 

1. Accept offer from company A and reject company B. But I still like company B more. 

2. Tell company A to wait a bit longer until I reach a decision, not next Monday. But I don't know whether this is a proper thing to do in business. 

3. Tell company B to make a decision to admit me as soon as possible before I go to another company. But I'm not sure whether I'm a strong enough candidate to make them admit me in a short period of time. 

Which option should I take? Thanks EECS101!!
history.subject: urgent... confirm an internship or wait for better offer?
